en.content:

{% block content %} 80/20 Training Rule: The Secret to Running Faster How elite runners train: 80% easy, 20% hardâ€”and why you should too What is the 80/20 Training Rule? The 80/20 training rule states that runners should do approximately 80% of their training at low intensity (easy pace, Zone 1-2 ) and 20% at moderate to high intensity (Zone 3-5). Running cadence (also called stride rate or turnover) is the number of steps you take per minute while running. It's measured by counting footstrikes of one foot and multiplying by two, or counting total steps for both feet combined. Cadence is one of the most important biomechanical factors affecting running e

fi.title: 80/20 Training Rule: The Secret to Running Faster
fi.description: How elite runners train: 80% easy, 20% hardâ€”and why you should too. 80/20 Training Rule: The Secret to Running Faster
fi.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} 80/20 Training Rule: The Secret to Running Faster How elite runners train: 80% easy, 20% hardâ€”and why you should too What is the 80/20 Training Rule? The 80/20 training rule states that runners should do approximately 80% of their training at low intensity (easy pace, Zone 1-2 ) and 20% at moderate to high intensity (Zone 3-5). This principle, backed by decades of research and practiced by elite runners worldwide, optimizes aerobic development while

fi.title: Base Building Phase: Foundation for Running Success
fi.description: How to build aerobic base that supports faster training and prevents injury. Base Building Phase: Foundation for Running Success
fi.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Base Building Phase: Foundation for Running Success How to build aerobic base that supports faster training and prevents injury What is Base Building? Base building is the foundational training phase where runners develop aerobic capacity through high-volume, low-intensity running. It's the most important phase of any training cycle , providing the physiological adaptations that support all future speed and race-specific work. Think of base building

fi.title: Gait Analysis for Runners: Complete Guide
fi.description: How to analyze and optimize your running form for better performance and injury prevention. Gait Analysis for Runners: Complete Guide
fi.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Gait Analysis for Runners: Complete Guide How to analyze and optimize your running form for better performance and injury prevention What is Gait Analysis? {% block content %} Lactate Threshold Testing: Complete Guide for Runners How to find your lactate threshold and use it to optimize marathon training What is Lactate Threshold? Lactate threshold (LT) is the exercise intensity at which lactate begins to accumulate in your bloodstream faster than your body can clear it. It represents the fastest pace you can sustain for extended periods (30-60 minutes) before fatigue forces you to slow down. For distance runners, lactate

hi.content:

{% block content %} Marathon Zone Distribution: How to Pace Your 26.2 Miles Science-based zone distribution strategies for optimal marathon performance What is Marathon Zone Distribution? Marathon zone distribution refers to how you allocate time across different intensity zones during a 26.2-mile race. Unlike shorter races where you can sustain higher intensities, marathons require careful pacing to avoid early depletion while maximizing performance. Understanding opt

hi.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Polarized Training for Runners: Train at Two Extremes Why elite endurance athletes avoid the middleâ€”training very easy and very hard What is Polarized Training? Polarized training is an intensity distribution model where runners spend approximately 75-85% of training time at low intensity ( Zone 1-2 ) and 10-20% at high intensity (Zone 5), while minimizing time in moderate intensity zones (Zone 3-4). hi.title: Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
hi.description: How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness. Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
hi.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness What are Zone 3 Tempo Runs? Zone 3 tempo runs are moderate-intensity sustained efforts run at approximately 70-80% of max heart rate or 85-95% of lactate threshold pace . They fall between easy aerobic runs (Zone 2) and hard threshold workouts (Zone 4), occupying the "tempo" zone that builds aerobic strength without exc

ja.title: Lactate Threshold Testing: Complete Guide for Runners
ja.description: How to find your lactate threshold and use it to optimize marathon training. Lactate Threshold Testing: Complete Guide for Runners
ja.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Lactate Threshold Testing: Complete Guide for Runners How to find your lactate threshold and use it to optimize marathon training What is Lactate Threshold? Lactate threshold (LT) is the exercise intensity at which lactate begins to accumulate in your bloodstream faster than your body can clear it. It represents the fastest pace you can sustain for extended periods (30-60 minutes) before fatigue forces you to slow down. For distance runners, lactate

ja.description: Science-based periodization strategies to prepare for your best marathon performance. Marathon Periodization: Complete Training Guide
ja.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Marathon Periodization: Complete Training Guide Science-based periodization strategies to prepare for your best marathon performance What is Periodization for Marathon Training? Periodization is the systematic planning of athletic training that divides your marathon preparation into distinct phases, each with specific goals and training stimuli. Rather than training the same way year-round, periodization strategically varies training volume, intensi

ja.title: Marathon Zone Distribution: How to Pace Your 26.2 Miles
ja.description: Science-based zone distribution strategies for optimal marathon performance. Marathon Zone Distribution: How to Pace Your 26.2 Miles
ja.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Marathon Zone Distribution: How to Pace Your 26.2 Miles Science-based zone distribution strategies for optimal marathon performance What is Marathon Zone Distribution? Marathon zone distribution refers to how you allocate time across different intensity zones during a 26.2-mile race. Unlike shorter races where you can sustain higher intensities, marathons require careful pacing to avoid early depletion while maximizing performance. Understanding opt

ja.title: Polarized Training for Runners: Train at Two Extremes
ja.description: Why elite endurance athletes avoid the middleâ€”training very easy and very hard. Polarized Training for Runners: Train at Two Extremes
ja.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Polarized Training for Runners: Train at Two Extremes Why elite endurance athletes avoid the middleâ€”training very easy and very hard What is Polarized Training? Polarized training is an intensity distribution model where runners spend approximately 75-85% of training time at low intensity ( Zone 1-2 ) and 10-20% at high intensity (Zone 5), while minimizing time in moderate intensity zones (Zone 3-4). This creates a "polarized" distribution with two

ja.content: Privacy-First Running Analytics: Your Data, Your Device Train smarter without compromising your privacy. ja.title: Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
ja.description: How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness. Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
ja.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness What are Zone 3 Tempo Runs? Zone 3 tempo runs are moderate-intensity sustained efforts run at approximately 70-80% of max heart rate or 85-95% of lactate threshold pace . They fall between easy aerobic runs (Zone 2) and hard threshold workouts (Zone 4), occupying the "tempo" zone that builds aerobic strength without exc

Lactate threshold (LT) is the exercise intensity at which lactate begins to accumulate in your bloodstream faster than your body can clear it. ko.title: Running Cadence: Complete Guide to Steps Per Minute

ko.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Running Cadence: Complete Guide to Steps Per Minute How to find your optimal cadence and improve running efficiency ëŸ¬ë‹ ì¼€ì´ë˜ìŠ¤ë€? Running cadence (also called stride rate or turnover) is the number of steps you take per minute while running. It's measured by counting footstrikes of one foot and multiplying by two, or counting total steps for both feet combined. Cadence is one of the most important biomechanical factors affecting running economy , injury

ko.title: Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
ko.description: How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness. Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot
ko.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Zone 3 Tempo Runs: Training in the Sweet Spot How to use moderate-intensity tempo runs to build aerobic strength and race readiness What are Zone 3 Tempo Runs? Zone 3 tempo runs are moderate-intensity sustained efforts run at approximately 70-80% of max heart rate or 85-95% of lactate threshold pace . They fall between easy aerobic runs (Zone 2) and hard threshold workouts (Zone 4), occupying the "tempo" zone that builds aerobic strength without exc

tl.title: Alituntuning 80/20 sa Pagsasanay: Ang Lihim sa Mas Mabilis na Pagtakbo
tl.description: Paano nagsasanay ang mga elite runner: 80% madali, 20% mabigatâ€”at bakit dapat mo ring gawin ito. Alituntuning 80/20 sa Pagsasanay: Ang Lihim sa Mas Mabilis na Pagtakbo
tl.content:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %} Alituntuning 80/20 sa Pagsasanay: Ang Lihim sa Mas Mabilis na Pagtakbo Paano nagsasanay ang mga elite runner: 80% madali, 20% mabigatâ€”at bakit dapat mo ring gawin ito Ano ang Alituntuning 80/20 sa Pagsasanay? Ang alituntuning 80/20 sa pagsasanay ay nagsasaad na ang mga runner ay dapat gumawa ng humigit-kumulang 80% ng kanilang pagsasanay sa mababang intensidad (madaling bilis, Zone 1-2 ) at 20% sa katamtaman hanggang mataas na intensidad (Zone 3-5).
